Study: Proactive social distancing mitigates COVID-19 outbreaks within a month across 58 mainland China cities
Factors: gathering bans; suspension of intra-city public transport; public service restrictions; case isolation; suspension of travel between cities; quarantine and social distancing
Excerpt: N/A; after the implementation of social distancing interventions, with an average reduction in the reproduction number (Rt) of 54.3% (SD 17.6%) over that time period
Measure of Evidence: Countries: China; Timeline:  February 14, 2020

Study: Impact of Social Distancing Measures on COVID-19 Healthcare Demand in Central Texas
Factors: school closures coupled with social distancing
Excerpt: ICU bed demand: 2,121 (95% CI: 2,018-2,208); ICU bed demand: 698 (95% CI: 204-1,100) with 75% social distancing and 136 (95% CI: 38-308) with 90% social distancing
Measure of Evidence: Countries: Texas, United States; Timeline: August 15th, 2020

Study: A Stratified Model to Quantify the Effects of Containment Policies on the Spread of COVID-19
Factors: schools and universities closed + elderly social distancing: interactions of [0-20] age groups decreases to 20%, interactions of 70+ age groups decreases to 25%
Excerpt: uncontained: eventual removed ratio 65.29%; maximum instantaneous infectious ratio 11.03%; R0 2.28; schools closed and elderly social distancing: eventual removed ratio 39.08%; maximum instantaneous infectious ratio 5.60%; R0 1.68
Measure of Evidence: Countries: Iran Timeline: first 90 days COVID-19 spread

Study: A Stratified Model to Quantify the Effects of Containment Policies on the Spread of COVID-19
Factors: schools, offices, and companies closed : interactions of [0-20] age groups decreases to 20% and interactions of [20-70] age range decreases to 50%
Excerpt: uncontained: eventual removed ratio 65.29%; maximum instantaneous infectious ratio 11.03%; R0 2.28; schools, offices, and companies closed: eventual removed ratio 24.97%; maximum instantaneous infectious ratio 3.98%; R0 1.49
Measure of Evidence: Countries: Iran Timeline: first 90 days COVID-19 spread

Study: Sustainable social distancing through facemask use and testing during the Covid-19 pandemic
Factors: social protection (e.g., facemask use, handwashing) and self-isolation after testing positive (TTI)
Excerpt: R0 has been estimated at 2.4; 65% effective social protection R < 1; , 20% effective social protection brings the reproduction number below 1.0 so long as 75% of the symptomatic population is covered by TTI within 12 hours of symptom onset (Fig. 1A and Appendix). Even with 20% effective social protection, TTI of 1 in 4 symptomatic individuals can substantially “flatten the curve”, cutting the peak daily incidence in half
Measure of Evidence: individuals : 10000000; Timeline: Unknown

Study: General Model for COVID-19 Spreading with Consideration of Intercity Migration, Insufficient Testing and Active Intervention: Application to Study of Pandemic Progression in Japan and USA
Factors: intercity travel and active intervention
Excerpt: if the level of active intervention is kept unchanged, the percentage of population eventually infected in Osaka-fu and Tokyo-to will reach around 12% and 4.2% of the population (around 2,300,000 and 600,000 people), respectively, and in total, Japan will have about 6.55% of its population eventually infected, if the level of active intervention remains at the status quo in the coming months, with California and New York state having around 15% and 37.5% of their population (5,800,000 and 7,300,000 people) eventually infected, respectively, and the overall infected population will reach 18.2%; implementing a four-fold elevated active intervention will improve the situation substantially, with the percentage of population infected in Osaka-fu and Tokyo-to reduced to 4.2% and 2.3%, respectively, and over 75% reduction in the overall number of infected cases in Japan, by implementing four-fold elevated active intervention, the percentage of infected population in the USA can be reduced to 9.3%.
Measure of Evidence: Countries: Japan, USA; Timeline: Jan 15th - March 20th

Study: The effect of control strategies to reduce social mixing on outcomes of the COVID-19 epidemic in Wuhan, China: a modelling study The Lancet Public Health
Factors: physical distancing measures with staggered return to work
Excerpt: N/A; Physical distancing measures were most effective if the staggered return to work was at the beginning of April; this reduced the median number of infections by more than 92% (IQR 66–97) and 24% (13–90) in mid-2020 and end-2020
Measure of Evidence: countries: China; cities: Wuhan; timeline: 1 year

Study: Interventions to mitigate early spread of SARS-CoV-2 in Singapore: a modelling study The Lancet Infectious Diseases
Factors: school closures; case isolation; workplace non-attendance; community contact reduction
Excerpt: For the baseline scenario, when R0 was 1·5, the median cumulative number of infections at day 80 was 279 000 (IQR 245 000–320 000), corresponding to 7·4% (IQR 6·5–8·5) of the resident population of Singapore. The median number of infections increased with higher infectivity: 727 000 cases (670 000–776 000) when R0 was 2·0, corresponding to 19·3% (17·8–20·6) of the Singaporean population, and 1 207 000 cases (1 164 000–1 249 000) when R0 was 2·5, corresponding to 32% (30·9–33·1) of the Singaporean population; Compared with the baseline scenario, the combined intervention was the most effective, reducing the estimated median number of infections by 99·3% (IQR 92·6–99·9) when R0 was 1·5, by 93·0% (81·5–99·7) when R0 was 2·0, and by 78·2% (59·0 −94·4) when R0 was 2·5. Assuming increasing asymptomatic fractions up to 50·0%, up to 277 000 infections were estimated to occur at day 80 with the combined intervention relative to 1800 for the baseline at R0 of 1·5.
Measure of Evidence: Countries: Singapore; Timeline: Day 80

Study: Effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of public health measures to control COVID-19: a modelling study
Factors: school closures; case isolation; workplace non-attendance; community contact reduction
Excerpt: N/A; The effective reproduction number (Re) was 1.84 (95%CI: 1.81, 1.87) and 3.80 (95%CI: 3.53, 4.06) respectively when the transmission constant was one in scenario I and II (Additional file 1: Table S4). Varying the transmission constant from the 0.25 to two, the isolation-and-quarantine was the most cost-effective single intervention, and program A was the most cost-effective joint intervention.

Study: The Effectiveness of Social Distancing in Mitigating COVID-19 Spread: a modelling analysis
Factors: school closures; case isolation; workplace non-attendance; community contact reduction
Excerpt: 66% infection rate (179,788 infected individuals) - no activation delay, SC = school closure , CI = case isolation, WN = workplace non-attendance , CCR = community contact reduction ; "SC + CI + 50% WN + 30% CCR: 1.14% IR (3,094), SC + CI + 90% WN + 70% CCR: 0.42% IR (1,131) "
Measure of Evidence: Countries: Australia; cities: Newcastle; Timeline: 10 weeks

Study: Impact of self-imposed prevention measures and short-term government intervention on mitigating and delaying a COVID-19 epidemic
Factors: school closures; case isolation; workplace non-attendance; community contact reduction
Excerpt: Baseline model predicts 46 diagnoses per 1000 individuals at the peak of the 199 epidemic, an attack rate of about 16% and the time to the peak of about 5.2 months; 65% reduction in the peak number of diagnoses, a 29% decrease in the 208 attack rate, and a delay in peak timing of 2.7 months
Measure of Evidence: Countries: Netherlands; Timeline: Unknown

Study: Spatially Explicit Modeling of 2019-nCoV Epidemic Trend based on Mobile Phone Data in Mainland China
Factors: self-isolation, quaratine, current control efforts
Excerpt: the current trend maintained, control efforts expanded, and person-to-person contact increased due to work resuming. We estimated that the total infections in mainland China would be 72172, 54348, and 149774 by March 12, 2020 under each scenario respectively; if the current trend is maintained (scenario 1), 95.4% cities can eliminate the disease by the end of February and all of them can succeed by March 12. With control efforts expanded (scenario 2), all cities except Wuhan will completely control the disease by the end of February. However, only 75.7% cities can completely win the battle against 2019-nCoV by the end of February if person-to-person contacts increase due to work resuming (scenario 3)
Measure of Evidence: Countries: China; Timeline: Feb 29th, 2020
